investigation.title: Relevance of Unfolded Protein Response to Spaceflight-Induced Transcriptional Reprogramming in Arabidopsis
investigation.description: Plants are primary producers of food and oxygen on Earth and will likewise be indispensable to the establishment of large-scale sustainable ecosystems and human survival in space. To contribute to the understanding of how plants respond to spaceflight stresses, we examined the relevance of the unfolded protein response (UPR), a conserved signaling cascade that responds to a number of unfavorable environmental stresses, in the model plant species Arabidopsis thaliana.

project.title: Mechanisms for Plant Adaptation to Space Environment
project.funding: This work was supported primarily by NASA NNX12AN71G with contributing support from Training Program in Plant Biotechnology for Health and Sustainability (T32-GM110523), the DOE Great Lakes Bioenergy Research Center (DOE BER Office of Science DE-FC02-07ER64494 and DE-SC0018409), the Chemical Sciences, Geosciences, and Biosciences Division, Office of Basic Energy Sciences, Office of Science, US Department of Energy (award number DE-FG02-91ER20021), National Institutes of Health (GM101038), and AgBioResearch (MICL02598) to F.B

publications.title: Relevance of the Unfolded Protein Response to Spaceflight-Induced Transcriptional Reprogramming in Arabidopsis
publications.summary: Relevance of the Unfolded Protein Response to Spaceflight-Induced Transcriptional Reprogramming in Arabidopsis â€” 10.1089/ast.2020.2313
